msItemStruct.note: Catalogue no. 29; Nelson collection no. N286. The scribe Petemestous, son of Poulemis(?) was also responsible for many burial tax receipts and one burial plot receipt from Thebes between years 20 and 24 of Ptolemy II. Amenothes, son of Parates is Muhs' Taxpayer 6. 1/2 silver kite was the usual payment to the Overseer of the Necropolis for the burial tax on the interment of one individual in the necropolis in the reign of Ptolemy II and hence 1 silver kite for the interment of two individuals. For another burial tax receipt in which the deceased may be designated a "man of the tomb of the town" (pa rmt ta st tmy), see DO Louvre 74 (Devauchelle 1983), although the editor took Ta-st-tmy as a toponym.

handDesc.p: Assuming that the ligature of the month number with the first sign of the season name includes part of the first sign, the reading akhet is excluded, and the curved shape of the third sign of the season name would favor peret over shemw.

div.ab: OIM 19319, recto: (1) Petemestous son of Poulemis(?) is the one who says to Amenothes son of Parates: you have given to me (2) 1 silver kite in the name of Ta-...(?) and Taibis, the shepherdess, (3) the people of the tomb of the town who were brought to the necropolis in the name of ... (4) ...Egyptian year 20, Mecheir 20, of pharaoh (5) Ptolemy (II) son of Ptolemy.
